Identifying personas in academic libraries can assist in library planning by focusing on patrons. Initially, personas were thought to be unique to each library; additional insights led the researchers to rethink this assertion. The purpose of this paper is to determine if personas, developed in one library, are unique or more universal than previously thought.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nDesign\/methodology\/approach<\/jats:title>\nIn this study, 903 surveys were completed across two institutions asking library patrons to identify use patterns within each library. Mean score responses were analyzed using an ANOVA, principal component analysis and RapidMiner technology. All analyses were used to identify personas with common interests and places personas in groups or neighborhoods.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nFindings<\/jats:title>\nThe findings provide evidence for the universality of academic library personas. However, differences occur in how the personas are grouped and use different library services and resources.<\/jats:p>\n<\/jats:sec>\n\nOriginality\/value<\/jats:title>\nPersonas allow librarians to view patrons in a more personal way as they connect personas to specific library spaces.
